data.text: Contents
Introduction

The National Health Service (NHS) has a statutory duty to deliver high quality patient care to all. The current definition of quality in healthcare was described in ‘High Quality Care of all: NHS next stage review' (Darzi, 2008), which was enshrined in law through the Health and Social Care Act 2012. The definition of high quality care includes three key aspects: patient safety, clinical effectiveness and patient experience.

There has been a focus in recent years upon clinical audit as a key healthcare quality improvement method; however, other data-driven methods are in many instances more fitting and complementary to clinical audit (HQIP 2015). Clinical audit and quality improvement are key core standards among professional groups. The General Medical Council's Good Medical Practice standards state that doctors “must take part in systems of quality assurance and quality improvement to promote patient safety. This includes…taking part in regular reviews and audits of your own work and that of your team, responding constructively to the outcomes, taking steps to address any problems and carrying out further training where necessary…” (GMC, April 2019). Likewise, the Nursing and Midwifery Council's The Code states that nurses must  ‘cooperate with all investigations and audits' (NMC, October 2018).

There are a number of statutory and mandatory requirements for trusts in quality improvement and clinical audit. These include the requirement that providers participate in mandatory national clinical audits and confidential inquires and report this in the annual Quality Accounts.

The Trust is committed to ensuring that high quality care is provided to all patients and that it continuously seeks to improve the quality of care it provides. The Trust views clinical audit and quality improvement methodology as two of the foundations from which to develop and maintain high quality patient-centred services and, as such, clinical audit plays a key role in the Trust's clinical governance agenda.
Purpose of this Policy

The purpose of this policy is to outline the management of clinical audit and quality improvement projects within the Trust and clarify the roles and responsibilities of all staff engaged in clinical audit activities, including the expectations of Care Groups and Divisions in the development and monitoring of local clinical audit programmes. The Trust will ensure that internal clinical audit functions are embedded and promote and support clinical quality by creating a culture that is committed to learning and continuously reviewing and improving the quality of care that it provides.

Clinical Audit
4.1.1 Principally, clinical audit serves three main functions:
As a tool for quality improvement
To  provide  corporate  assurance  through  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  of performance
To demonstrate compliance against standards
4.1.2 Clinical audit is often described as a cycle where different stages are followed. Typically, the stages are:
the identification of best practice (standards) that should be followed
the measurement of current practice against best practice
the implementation of changes to improve practice where gaps are identified
monitoring or re-auditing of current practice to ensure that improvements have been implemented effectively, are sustained and have improved the quality of
care provided.

Scope
Target Audience
This policy applies to anyone engaged in the clinical audit process within the Trust, including:
All staff, including clinical and non-clinical.
Students and trainees
Patients, carers, volunteers, and members of the public.
This policy also applies when clinical audit is undertaken jointly across organisational boundaries.
5.2.1 Multi-disciplinary and multi-professional audit and partnership working with other organisations

5.2.2 The Trust encourages clinical audit to be undertaken jointly across professional and organisational boundaries. Partnership working with other local and regional organisations will be encouraged where improvements to the patient journey may be identified through shared clinical audit activity. The Trust also supports collaboration on multi-professional clinical audits of interest to other parts of the local health and care economy, both within and outside of the NHS, e.g. community/secondary care, local authorities, independent health and social care providers.
Involving patients and the public

The Trust promotes a commitment to involve patients, carers, and members of the public in the clinical audit process, either indirectly through the use of patient surveys and questionnaires, or directly through participation of patients, carers, and members of the public on clinical audit project steering groups or quality improvement patient panels.
Involving medical students and junior doctors

Foundation Programme doctors are expected to participate in clinical audits or to complete a quality improvement project. They are also expected to collect evidence about their learning from clinical audit and QI. The Trust is committed to supporting both junior doctors' and medical students' involvement in clinical audit and quality improvement, which will make an important contribution to improving patient care in the Trust.
Duties, roles, and responsibilities

Chief Executive is the trust's accounting officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. This responsibility can be delegated.
Chief Medical Officer is the executive lead for clinical audit and quality chairs the MSE Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group (CAEG).

Chief Nursing Officer  is also responsible for quality and for ensuring that the necessary systems and processes are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this policy.

Lead for Clinical Audit provides clinical leadership for the strategic development of clinical audit activities and Trust wide support for the review of clinical audit information and implementation of recommendations. The lead is responsible for ensuring that Care Groups & Divisions receive reports on the progress of clinical audits and quality improvement projects and for ensuring that divisions have effective clinical audit and quality improvement programmes in place. They are a standing member of the CAEG.

Associate Clinical Director for Improvement provides support to ensure that the corporate and divisional clinical audit and quality improvement programmes are aligned with Trust priorities and goals. They will provide expert knowledge on quality improvement methodology where needed. They are also a standing member of the CAEG.

Site Medical Directors are the local leads for clinical audit. They are responsible for providing assurance to the Board of Directors that services are safe and effective and to prioritise the Trust's participation in national clinical audit. They attend the CAEG.

Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that sufficient time is allocated to enable clinicians to participate in regular clinical audit and that they attend clinical audit meetings as and when required.

Divisional Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement leads  are responsible for supporting the development of divisional annual clinical audit and quality improvement programmes. They will promote clinical audit within their speciality and division; provide advice on clinical audit and quality improvement methodology, and support to staff in the initiation of clinical audit and quality improvement projects. They are responsible for reporting on clinical audits to the CAEG and to their Care Groups/Divisional Clinical Governance Groups and for ensuring that information from the CAEG is cascaded within their Division. They are also responsible for reviewing clinical audit/quality improvement registration forms with a view to approving or declining the project.
Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit Team is responsible for:

Providing support to the Trust for clinical audit (including quality improvement projects) including facilitation, project management and undertaking some corporate clinical audit and quality improvement activity;
Contributing to the delivery of clinical audit and quality improvement training;
Maintaining a database/register of clinical audit activity within the Trust;
Providing regular and bespoke monitoring and exception reports relating to clinical audit and produce the Clinical Audit Annual Report;
Reviewing reports of national clinical audits and sending a summary to the relevant department for action planning in conjunction with NICE guidance;
Providing information for the annual Quality Accounts and other statutory submissions, such as Data Security and Protection Toolkit and NHS Resolution standards;
Maintaining regular contact with the Divisional Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Leads, providing support and guidance where required or requested;
Supporting divisions in the development of their annual clinical audit and quality improvement priority programmes;
Providing support and advice in maintaining standards in clinical audit (e.g. information security, Caldicott Guardian principles)
Supporting CAEG by providing reports and updates on the progress of the clinical audit programme.

Medical staff  must regularly review their own work and keep up to date by undertaking clinical audit and quality improvement in order to maintain their registration with the General Medical Council. This activity must always be undertaken in line with the divisional clinical audit priority plans. Senior clinicians are expected to supervise those projects undertaken by junior doctors. Healthcare Professionals are responsible for ensuring that they participate in regular clinical audit and that they have appropriate knowledge and skills to facilitate the successful completion of the clinical audit cycle and respond to audit results appropriately in relation to changing, measuring and developing practice.
Care Group and Divisional governance boards are responsible for:
The development and approval of Divisional annual clinical audit priority programmes;
Reviewing information relating to national and local clinical audit activity and agreeing any actions required;
Approving implementation plans arising from clinical audit projects;
Monitoring the implementation of actions as a result of national and local clinical audit;
Ensuring that overdue audits and action plans are addressed in a timely way.

Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group (CAEG) assists the Trust in the delivery of strategic clinical audit and effectiveness objectives and to ensure that annual divisional and corporate clinical audit and quality improvement programmes are developed and completed. It is chaired by the chief medical officer.
Risk and Compliance Group (RCG) monitors compliance to this policy through Divisional reporting and the Clinical Audit Annual Report.

Patient Safety and Quality Group (PSQG) receives and considers clinical audit reports relating to patient safety issues and recommend and monitors the implementation of actions to improve quality and patient safety.
Quality Governance Committee receives items relating to clinical audit and quality improvement by exception and via escalation from RCG and PSQG.

Conduct of Clinical Audit
Agreeing an Annual Programme of Activity

Prior to the start of every financial year, the Trust will agree an appropriate planned programme of corporate clinical audit and quality improvement activity that will meet the Trust's corporate requirements for assurance.

8.1.1 At local level, each division will also establish a rolling, risk-based annual priority programme of clinical audit and quality improvement with support being provided by the clinical audit teams to agree the content. These will be managed within the Care Groups and Divisions.
Working with Commissioners

The Trust will endeavour to consult with its commissioners to identify clinical audit (and quality improvement) programme requirements, such as CQUINS, and will work collaboratively on agreed interface clinical audits.
Choosing and Prioritising Clinical Audit Topics
Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group and the Priority Programme

Members of the CAEG in conjunction with the Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams will produce a data pack for each division on a rolling annual basis to facilitate the development of their priority clinical audit and quality improvement programme. The data pack will include evidence from sources including NICE guidance, national clinical audits and reports of external reviews. (Appendix 3 gives an overview of the process).
Clinical Audit Categories

There are three types of clinical audit projects undertaken within the Trust; Corporate, Compliance and Clinical Practice which can fall into the following categories (which will have an impact on the content of programme):
External ‘must do' audits, such as mandatory national clinical audits
Internal ‘must do' audits, such as those relating to areas of high risk for the Trust
Divisional work plan, based on divisional priority plans
Clinician Interest
NB. One of the most important stages in developing the programme is to identify the ‘must do' audits.
Participation in National Audits

The list of national clinical audits that Trusts are mandated to participate in is published by the Healthcare Quality Improvement Partnership (HQIP) in January. The Trust aims to participate in all relevant mandatory national clinical audit studies. The clinical audit team will contact leads to confirm participation. Where funding is required to participate in a national clinical audit, it is the responsibility of each Care Group/Division to ensure resources are identified in the business planning process.

9.3.1  Where the service is not planning on participating in a mandatory national clinical audit this must be discussed and agreed through the division's clinical governance process. It will be reported to CAEG and RCG by exception.
National Clinical Audit Reports

The Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit Teams will monitor HQIP and other relevant sites to identify the publication of relevant national clinical audit reports. An executive summary of these reports will be prepared within one month of publication and sent to the lead for that audit to enable action planning. The lead must also review any associated NICE guidance alongside the executive summary report to ensure consistency.
Corporate Clinical Audits

These are high level projects aimed at providing assurance to the Trust Board and addressing areas of high risk. They are typically related to the Board Assurance Framework (BAF), high level incidents and risks. The draft corporate clinical audit programme is developed on an annual basis by the Clinical Audit Team and agreed at the Quality Governance Committee.
Local Clinical Practice Audits/quality improvement projects

These projects reflect local priorities and those identified by divisions around areas of high risk or concern where it is deemed that quality could be improved. They are usually undertaken within a specific specialty although it is important that multi- professional audits and audits with other specialties and organisations are carried out. Projects conducted as part of junior doctor training typically fall into this category. Mortality reviews are a special type of clinical audit that look specifically at the care of patients who have died to identify any learning points.
Use of Databases

Data provided on registration will be used to compile a database of all clinical audit activity undertaken throughout the Trust. The database will be updated regularly by the Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams and will be used to provide reports to the relevant group of committee as part of the clinical governance process.
The Use of Standards (or Criteria) in Clinical Audit

Clinical audit involves measuring clinical practice against standards with expectations of the target for achievement (NICE 2002, HQIP 2009c). The Trust expects clinical standards to be presented in a format which conforms to ‘Principles for Best Practice in Clinical Audit – 2002'. Proposed data collection tools and methods should be identified on the registration form submitted as part of the registration process.

9.8.1  It  is  recognised  that  there  may  be  occasions  when  there  are  no  clear  written standards and in these cases, clinicians should agree and define their expectations prior to commencing an audit.
Reporting and Presentation

A project report/presentation should be completed for every clinical audit/quality improvement project completed. It is preferred that the Trust clinical audit outcome form be used and the form must ‘signed-off' by the clinical audit lead of the relevant specialty. From the outset the lead for the project is asked to consider the most appropriate forum to present the results.
Dissemination

The findings of clinical audit/quality improvement projects should be shared with the relevant individuals, departments, managers and patients in a timely manner to ensure that key stakeholders have the opportunity to contribute to the identification of recommendations and development of action plans.

9.10.1 The usual forum for the dissemination of clinical audit findings is the Divisional / Specialty clinical audit meetings where the findings should be discussed, action plans agreed and a commitment to re-audit made (if relevant). Where formal presentation is not possible or there is a significant delay between the completion of the project and the date for formal presentation (for instance of more than two months), the project lead should ensure the report of the findings are disseminated to the appropriate individuals as soon as possible. The action plans for all completed projects are included in the relevant divisional clinical audit reports.
Action Plans for Improvement

Where the result of clinical audit identifies areas for improvement, recommendations should be made and a clear action plan developed to support the implementation of these actions within a timely manner.

9.11.1 The clinical audit outcome form must be completed for each clinical audit project (unless a formal report containing detailed results with the action plan). The outcome information should be submitted to the Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams on completion of the project (NB. This applies to clinical audits and not to quality improvement projects as the PDSA cycles are executed as the project is in process).

9.11.2 Where outcome information has not been received, the project lead and supervisor will be prompted to provide the information and this will also be highlighted in the division clinical audit report (the clinical audit lead for the division will also be informed). All action plans must be in the Trust format and actions must be SMART.

9.11.3 The Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Teams will review outcome information provided to ensure that any recommendations address the areas of concern. Where the form does not fully address the areas of concern, the project lead will be contacted and asked to review the action plan.

9.11.4 Outcome information is documented on the clinical audit database including any actions and expected completion dates. The Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams might ask clinical audit leads to provide an update on progress with action plans at planned intervals determined by the timescales identified within the action plan.
Publications

Any staff member wishing to publish any results or findings from an audit undertaken at MSEFT will be supported to do so providing that the audit was registered with the audit team at time of commencement. Any authors submitting reports of Trust audits for publication without the prior approval of the Trust may face disciplinary proceedings. Any member of staff wishing to publish a clinical audit report should contact their site clinical audit team for further advice.
Repeating Audit Cycles

Audits where actions have been implemented should be considered for re-audit. The Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams will provide Divisions/Specialties with a list of audits fitting this criterion and these should be considered when planning the annual divisional clinical audit programme and prioritised accordingly.
Clinical Audit Annual Report

An annual clinical audit report will be produced by the clinical audit team and submitted to the Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group for initial approval, and following that to Quality Governance Committee and the Board.
Governance and Ethics
Ethics and Consent

By definition, clinical audit projects should not require formal approval from a Research & Ethics Committee. However, one of the principles underpinning clinical audit is that the process should do good and not do harm. Clinical audit must always be conducted within an ethical framework which considers the following four principles:
There is a benefit to existing or future patients or others that outweighs potential burdens or risks
Each patient's right to self-determination is respected
Each patient's privacy and confidentiality are preserved
The activity is fairly distributed across patient groups

Further information is available in the Health Quality Improvement Programme guide ‘Ethics and Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Literature: a guide on Ethics and Clinical Audit'. (HQIP, February 2017)
Equality and Diversity

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all its users and clinical audit activity must take account of equality and diversity issues. The Trust will ensure that the process for determining choice of clinical audit projects, and the manner in which project patient samples are drawn up, does not inadvertently discriminate against any groups in society based on their race, disability, gender, age, sexual orientation, religion and belief.
Information Governance: Collection, Storage and Retention of Data and Confidentiality

All clinical audit activity must take account of the General Data Protection Regulation (2018) and the Data Protection Act (2016), the Caldicott Principles (1997 & 2013) and the MSE Information Governance & Management Policy. This means that data should be:
Adequate, relevant and not excessive;
Accurate;
Processed for limited purposes;
Held securely;
Not kept for longer than is necessary;
Audit data held electronically should be stored on a server according to the trust local policy
Shared appropriately and safely in the best interests of their patients
National Data Opt-Out

The National Data Guardian's Review of Data Security, Consent and Opt-Outs (NDG Review, July 2016) proposed that here should be a new consent/opt-out model to allow people to opt-out of their personal confidential data being used for purposes beyond their direct care.

10.4.1 A patient/service user is able to set an opt-out via a number of channels that include online, digitally assisted and non-digital channels. Any person who has an NHS number allocated to them is able to set a national data opt-out. The opt-out is stored in a central repository against their NHS number on ‘the Spine', and is effective from the date the opt-out is set.

10.4.2 Prior to implementation of submitting National Clinical Audit data, the department must send a list of NHS numbers of the identified subjects/participants to the Healthcare Analytics Team at  now  mse.analysis.reporting@nhs.net  and must include “OPT OUT” as the subject of the email. The Healthcare Analytics Team will check the list against the national database on the Spine system. This will generate a definitive list with any NHS numbers registered for opt-out extracted, which will be returned to the department for use.

10.4.3 A copy of the report must be dated and filed, and retained by the relevant department in line with Records Management Code of Practice for Health and Social Care 2016, in order to evidence that the National Opt-Out requirements have been satisfied

10.4.4 NB. The National Data Opt-Out is only applicable to National Clinical Audit submitting patient identifying data. (More details can be found in MSE Data Opt-Out Policy MSEPO-20207 and on the NHS Digital National Data Opt-Out site.)
Training and Development

Some aspects of clinical audit and quality improvement require specialist skills, for example using the correct clinical audit methodology. Training raises the profile of clinical audit and awareness of best practice standards, builds capacity and capability for the reflective practice of all those involved, and acts as a driver for quality improvement.
Provision of Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Training
Clinical audit training

The Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams will make suitable training/support available for all healthcare professionals wishing to undertake clinical audit. Dedicated training sessions are offered, although bespoke training can be provided to groups or individuals on request.
Quality Improvement Training Sessions
The Clinical Effectiveness/Clinical Audit teams will offer 1:1 QI methodology training with a view to:
The definition of quality in healthcare and what quality means to the Trust.
The definition and importance of quality improvement in healthcare.
The IHI's Model for improvement and its applicability, including use of PDSA cycles.
The difference between QI and audit, focussing on measurement for improvement.
12.2.1 For more in-depth training on quality improvement the Trust runs a Quality Service Improvement Redesign Practitioner (QSIR-P) accredited course.
Employment and Development of Clinical Audit Staff

The Trust will employ a team of suitably skilled clinical audit staff to support the programme of clinical audit activity. The Trust will also ensure that staff have access to further relevant training in order to maintain and develop their knowledge and skills.

Clinical  audit  staff  will  be  expected  to  participate  in  professional  training  and development activities including those organised by HQIP, the National Quality Improvement (including Clinical Audit) Network (N-QI-CAN) and QSIR-P.
Monitoring and Auditing
In  order  to  ensure  compliance  with  the  strategy,  the  Trust  will  undertake  the following monitoring.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Clinical Audit and Effectiveness guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Appendix 1 – Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group TOR
CLINICAL AUDIT AND EFFECTIVENESS GROUP
Terms of Reference

1.1. The purpose of the Group is to assist the Trust in the delivery of strategic clinical audit and effectiveness  objectives and to ensure that annual divisional and corporate clinical audit and quality improvement programmes are developed and completed.
2.1. To direct, review and monitor the Trust's corporate clinical audit programme
2.2. To monitor participation with and outcomes from mandatory national clinical audits
2.3. To monitor compliance to NICE guidance
2.4. To monitor compliance to NCEPOD recommendations
2.5. To update and monitor the Clinical Audit strategy.

2.6. To produce reports on the Clinical Audit Programme in line with current national and local initiatives and priorities and representing all types of clinical audit and quality improvement work being undertaken in the Trust.
2.7. To consider and agree key indicators to measure the effectiveness of the Trust Clinical Audit Programme and the quality of clinical audit and quality improvement projects.
2.8. To provide assurance that the quality and outcome of clinical audit projects undertaken in the Trust are reviewed and to monitor the implementation of identified changes.
2.9. To provide information and feedback on the clinical audit programme and NICE compliance for Divisions and provide assurance that these are completed.
2.10. To produce an annual Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Report summarising projects undertaken, achievement of change through the clinical audit process and compliance to NICE guidance.
2.11. To delegate responsibility for clinical audit and effectiveness activity to the divisions and receive exception reports

5.1. The quorum for any meeting of the Group will be a minimum of six members, one of whom must be the Chief Medical Officer or Site Medical Director and at least five other divisional / directorate representatives.

6.1. A representative (nominated deputy) must attend in the absence of members of the divisional / directorate representatives. Attendance is compulsory. Members are expected to make every effort to attend all meetings of the Clinical Audit and Effectiveness group with a minimum attendance of 75% (3/4) of meetings within each reporting year. An attendance register will be taken at each meeting and an annual register of attendance will be included in the meeting papers.
6.2. Members attend primarily to represent their function or division / directorate, but may also be co-opted for specific projects as required to meet the objectives of the group.

7.1. Members may, in exceptional circumstances, nominate a suitable deputy to attend meetings and make decisions on their behalf. Attendance by a nominated deputy must be notified in advance to the Chair of the Group.
7.2. A register of approved deputies will be maintained as part of the Group's register of attendance
8.1. The Trust Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group is accountable to the Quality Governance Committee.

8.2. The divisions/directorates report the management of their clinical audits and compliance position to their Board and Governance Meetings and will be expected to provide an exception report on activity to the clinical audit and effectiveness group
8.3. The NICE Implementation Group will report to the Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group.
8.4. The Trust Clinical Audit and Effectiveness Group will provide an annual report for the Quality Governance Committee and Audit Committee
9.1. The Clinical Audit and Effectiveness group shall meet on a quarterly basis for 1 1/2 hours. Additional meetings may be convened on an exceptional basis at the discretion of the Group Chair.
10.1. The draft minutes and action log will be shared with all members within ten working days following the meeting in question.
10.2. The draft agenda will be developed and agreed ten working days in advance of the meeting
10.3. All reports to the group will be submitted 7 working days before the meeting
10.4. The complete agenda pack will be circulated at least five working days before the date of the meeting.
